text.p: These are the leading stories in the Serbian and Montenegrin press on Friday. Reuters has not verified them and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- SERBIA -
POLITIKA

- Serbs in Eastern Slavonia to decide at their regional parliament if they will participate in the upcoming local elections because of irregularities in issuance of Croatian documents and election lists.

- Serbian government promises association of Serbian hard currency depositors to make a program for servicing the frozen foreign currency reserves. Depositors agree not to protest while solutions sought.

- Banks within the system of Belgrade bank Beogradska Banka AD agree to form in mid-May specialised bank for foreign credit relations and rehabilitation and financing of member banks which will be called Beogradska Banka Group.
- Yugoslav prices were stable in the first three months this year because of the central bank's extremely restrictive monetary policy, say economists.
- The National Bank of Yugoslavia will maintain its policy of increasing money supply only through hard currency transactions, says Vice-Governor of the central bank Ratko Banovic.

- Ruling Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS) will not participate in the Serbia-Kosovo Albanian round table in New York because it considers talks on the issue can only be conducted in the country, says spokesman.
NASA BORBA
- Leaders of opposition coalition Zajedno deny there are serious conflicts between them amid frequent media reports about their disagreements.
- Bakers ask for increase of bread price and express dissatisfaction with the 3.5 dinar price proposed by the government.
- The new proposed privatisation law is conducive to the election campaign, says economic adviser of opposition Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO).
- Non-governmental organisations will organise a protest gathering in Belgrade to mark fifth anniversary of the beginning of war in Bosnia.

- First group of 69 Kosovo Albanians from Germany arrived in Pristina under the German-Yugoslav agreement last year on the repatriation of 120,000 refugees. Over 80 percent of the refugees are Kosovo Albanians.
VECERNJE NOVOSTI
- Yugoslav army is still on alert at the country's borders with Albania, border crossings Vrbinci near Prizren and Caf Prusi near Djakovica are still closed.

- Textile, metal and other workers in Leskovac, southern Serbia, continue protests started on Monday demanding reduction of electricity and utility prices, delay of debt repayment and restarting of production.
POLITIKA EKSPRES
- Yugoslav-Croatian expert teams start new round of talks in Zagreb.
BORBA
- Federal government remains founder of daily Borba.
- Serbian wine-makers ask for redistribution of taxes and excise duties.
- Agricultural machine factory 25 Maj from Kikinda concludes agreement with Germany's FAB for production of forklifts.
- MONTENEGRO -
POBJEDA
- Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic received Metropolitain Amfilohije Radovic, the head of the Serbian Orthodox Church in Montenegro. They visited the building site of a new church in Podgorica.
- Podgorica aluminum plant needs a long-term credit of $30 million to continue production.
- Italian consul in Montenegro Stephano Mistreta donated books to Kotor and Niksic. -- Belgrade Newsroom +381 11 2224254
